senses.definition: a period of time spent travelling or relaxing away from home

examples.x: They're on vacation in Hawaii right now.
I'm going on vacation for a couple of weeks.
You look tired—you should take a vacation.
We're planning a summer vacation to Europe next year.
I just got back from a family vacation in New Orleans.
The job includes two weeks' paid vacation.
a vacation home
He had a lot of unused vacation time.

senses.definition: (in the UK) one of the periods of time when universities or courts of law are closed; (in the US) one of the periods of time when schools, colleges, universities or courts of law are closed

examples.x: the Christmas/Easter/summer vacation
the long vacation (= the summer vacation)
I got a full-time job during the vacation.

senses.definition: a space that is completely empty of all substances, including all air or other gas

examples.x: a vacuum pump (= one that creates a vacuum)
vacuum-packed foods (= in a package from which most of the air has been removed)

senses.definition: a situation in which somebody/something is missing

examples.x: His resignation has created a vacuum which cannot easily be filled.
The writer criticized the moral vacuum in society.

senses.definition: the act of cleaning something with a vacuum cleaner

examples.x: to give a room a quick vacuum

senses.definition: existing separately from other people, events, etc. when there should be a connection

examples.x: This kind of decision cannot ever be made in a vacuum.

senses.definition: not clear in a person’s mind

examples.x: to have a vague impression/memory/recollection of something
They had only a vague idea where the place was.

senses.definition: not having or giving enough information or details about something

examples.x: She's a little vague about her plans for next year.
The politicians made vague promises about tax cuts.
He was accused of being deliberately vague.
We had only a vague description of the attacker.
He outlined the policy in vague terms.

senses.definition: suggesting a lack of clear thought or attention

examples.x: His vague manner concealed a brilliant mind.
She seems to be getting rather vague as she grows older.

senses.definition: not having a clear shape

examples.x: In the darkness they could see the vague outline of a church.

senses.definition: that is legally or officially acceptable

examples.x: Do you have a valid passport?
He bought a bus pass valid for one month.
They have a valid claim to compensation.

senses.definition: based on what is logical or true

examples.x: She had valid reasons for not supporting the proposals.
The point you make is perfectly valid.
That argument is not strictly valid in this case.

senses.definition: that is accepted by the system

examples.x: a valid password

senses.definition: the state of being legally or officially acceptable

examples.x: The period of validity of the agreement has expired.

senses.definition: the state of being logical and true

examples.x: We had doubts about the validity of their argument.

senses.definition: an area of low land between hills or mountains, often with a river flowing through it; the land that a river flows through

examples.x: In the valley below cows were grazing peacefully.
the fertile soils of river valleys
A stream runs the length of the valley floor.
the Shenandoah Valley
the valley of the Nile
a small town set in a valley
The cottage was in a wooded valley.
The road climbs up the side of the valley.

senses.definition: worth a lot of money

examples.x: My home is my most valuable asset.
She claims hospitals waste valuable resources by admitting patients days before surgery.
valuable antiques
Luckily, nothing valuable was stolen.

senses.definition: very useful or important

examples.x: a valuable experience/lesson
You should gain some valuable insights into the world of business.
documents that are enormously valuable to historians
The book provides valuable information on recent trends.
He had already made a valuable contribution to economic theory.
The results will be a valuable tool for further research in the area.
This advice was to prove valuable.
Spinach is a valuable source of iron.
The data will be extremely valuable for medical research.
a simple blood test that is very valuable in the management of diabetes
Student input can be particularly valuable in improving the teaching process.

senses.definition: how much something is worth in money or other goods for which it can be exchanged

examples.x: to go up/rise/increase in value
to go down/fall/decline in value
rising property values
The value of the shares has continued to fall.
The winner will receive a prize to the value of £1 000.
Don't leave anything of value in the car.
Sports cars tend to hold their value well.

senses.definition: how much something is worth compared with its price

examples.x: to be good/great value (= worth the money it costs)
to be bad/poor value (= not worth the money it costs)
Larger sizes give the best value for money.
The hotel gives value for money.
They're only £40—not bad value, really.
This great value-for-money offer is only available to society members.

senses.definition: the quality of being useful or important

examples.x: The value of regular exercise should not be underestimated.
She placed a high value on loyalty.
He didn't say anything of value.
The arrival of canals was of great value to many industries.
to be of little/no value to somebody
The library's value to the community is enormous.
This ring has great sentimental value for me.
I suppose it has a certain novelty value (= it's interesting because it's new).
food with a high nutritional value
The story has very little news value.
Branding has to add value to the product.

senses.definition: beliefs about what is right and wrong and what is important in life

examples.x: We need to be guided by our moral values.
a return to traditional values in education, such as firm discipline
The school's core values include the ability to work with others.
The young have a completely different set of values and expectations.

senses.definition: the amount represented by a letter or symbol

examples.x: Let y have the value 33.

senses.definition: to think that somebody/something is important

examples.x: He has come to value her advice and support.
They don’t seem to value honesty very highly.
I really value him as a friend.
The area is valued for its vineyards.
She's a valued member of staff.

senses.definition: to decide that something is worth a particular amount of money

examples.x: The property has been valued at over $2 million.
You should get the painting valued.

senses.definition: a covered vehicle with no side windows in its back half, usually smaller than a lorry, used for carrying goods or people

examples.x: the driver of a white van
a police van (= for carrying police officers or prisoners)
A delivery van was almost blocking the narrow street.
an ice-cream van
a van driver
A passenger in the van was fatally injured.
He usually sleeps in the back of his van.

senses.definition: a covered vehicle with side windows, usually smaller than a lorry, that can carry about twelve passengers
a closed coach on a train for carrying bags, cases, etc. or mail

examples.x: a luggage van
The gang robbed a mail van, seriously injuring one of the guards.

senses.definition: at the front or in the leading position

examples.x: These artists felt themselves in the van of the movement, true pioneers.

senses.definition: to disappear suddenly and/or in a way that you cannot explain

examples.x: He turned around and vanished into the house.
The magician vanished in a puff of smoke.
My glasses seem to have vanished.
He vanished without trace.

senses.definition: to stop existing

examples.x: the vanishing woodlands of Europe
All hopes of a peaceful settlement had now vanished.
All thoughts of leaving vanished from his mind.

senses.definition: to disappear completely

examples.x: Keep looking—they can't just have vanished off the face of the earth.

senses.definition: to disappear suddenly in a mysterious way

examples.x: She can’t just have vanished into thin air.
At a stroke she could make things vanish into thin air.

senses.definition: to go away or be impossible to find when people need or want you

examples.x: The cat had done a disappearing act.

senses.definition: often changing; likely to change

examples.x: variable temperatures
The acting is of variable quality (= some of it is good and some of it is bad).

senses.definition: able to be changed

examples.x: The drill has variable speed control.
The kitchen boasts stylish units and variable lighting.
These systems are infinitely variable.

senses.definition: a situation, number or quantity that can vary or be varied

examples.x: With so many variables, it is difficult to calculate the cost.
The temperature remained constant while pressure was a variable in the experiment.

senses.definition: a change, especially in the amount or level of something

examples.x: The dial records very slight variations in pressure.
Currency exchange rates are always subject to variation.
regional/seasonal variation (= depending on the region or time of year)

senses.definition: a thing that is different from other things in the same general group

examples.x: This soup is a spicy variation on a traditional favourite.

senses.definition: any of a set of short pieces of music based on a simple tune repeated in a different and more complicated form

examples.x: a set of variations on a theme by Mozart
His numerous complaints are all variations on a theme (= all about the same thing).

senses.definition: of many different types

examples.x: varied opinions
They stock a wide and varied selection of cheeses.

senses.definition: not staying the same, but changing often

examples.x: He led a full and varied life.
I've had a varied career.

senses.definition: several different sorts of the same thing

examples.x: There is a wide variety of patterns to choose from.
He resigned for a variety of reasons.
This tool can be used in a variety of ways.
The text consists of extracts from a variety of sources.
articles and essays on a variety of topics
I don't eat meat, only fish, but there's a good variety available here.
The day-long excursion is one of a variety on offer for tourists.
I was impressed by the variety of dishes on offer.

senses.definition: the quality of not being the same or not doing the same thing all the time

examples.x: It's the variety that makes my job so enjoyable.
We all need variety in our diet.
We want more variety in our work.
a constant craving for variety and adventure
The festival demonstrates the variety of the UK music scene.

senses.definition: a type of a thing, for example a plant or language, that is different from the others in the same general group

examples.x: Apples come in a great many varieties.
different varieties of English
This is a very rare variety of orchid.
A typical estate in the region will grow at least three grape varieties.
My cooking is of the ‘quick and simple’ variety.

senses.definition: a form of theatre or television entertainment that consists of a series of short performances, such as singing, dancing and funny acts

examples.x: a variety show/theatre

senses.definition: having a range of different experiences makes life more interesting
several different

examples.x: various types/forms/kinds of somebody/something
We talked about jobs, family, football and various other things.
documentaries that explored various aspects of life in Germany
Tents come in various shapes and sizes.
She took the job for various reasons.
There are various ways of doing this.
He spent his childhood in various parts of Italy.
Various groups use the centre.
Data will be collected at various stages.
My films involve various different points of view.
Members of the various political parties were calling for something to be done.
His complaints were many and various.

senses.definition: having many different features

examples.x: a large and various country

senses.definition: to be different from each other in size, shape, etc.

examples.x: New techniques were introduced with varying degrees of success.
Estimates of how many civilians were killed varied widely.
Class size varies greatly.
The students' work varies considerably in quality.
The rooms vary in size.
There are a number of routes to the summit, with varying levels of difficulty.

senses.definition: to change or be different according to the situation

examples.x: The menu varies with the season.
Cancer rates vary significantly by gender and ethnicity.
Results can vary greatly from year to year.
Pulse rates vary slightly from person to person.
Class numbers vary between 25 and 30.
Costs are likely to vary depending on where you live.
‘What time do you start work?’ ‘It varies.’
Prices vary according to the type of room you require.

senses.definition: to make changes to something to make it slightly different

examples.x: The job enables me to vary the hours I work.
The aerobics instructor varies the routine each week.
Consumers may apply to the lender to vary the terms of their contract.
Drivers need to take note of the weather conditions and vary their speed accordingly.

senses.definition: used to say that people may experience a particular thing in different ways

examples.x: Highly recommend the company! Of course, your mileage may vary.

senses.definition: extremely large in area, size, amount, etc.

examples.x: a vast area of forest
a vast crowd
In the vast majority of cases, this should not be a problem.
They sell a vast array of products.
a vast amount of information
At dusk bats appear in vast numbers.
vast quantities of food
His business empire was vast.
vast sums of money
The special effects were a vast improvement over the original film.
She writes on a vast range of subjects.
It is a very rich country with vast resources.
Your help made a vast difference.
We’ve hired a marquee at vast expense.

senses.definition: a plant or part of a plant that is eaten as food. Potatoes, beans and onions are all vegetables.

examples.x: The children don't eat enough fresh vegetables.
root vegetables (= for example carrots)
a vegetable garden
We grow our own vegetables.
a salad of raw vegetables
organic vegetables
a vegetable patch/plot
vegetable soup
vegetable matter (= plants in general)

senses.definition: an offensive word for a person who is physically alive but not capable of much mental or physical activity, for example because of a serious accident or illness
a person who has a boring life

examples.x: Since losing my job I've been a vegetable.

senses.definition: a thing that is used for transporting people or goods from one place to another, such as a car or lorry

examples.x: motor vehicles (= cars, buses, lorries, etc.)
Are you the driver of this vehicle?
The police think that he was driving a stolen vehicle.
rows of parked vehicles

senses.definition: something that can be used to express your ideas or feelings, or as a way of achieving something

examples.x: Art may be used as a vehicle for propaganda.
The play is an ideal vehicle for her talents.

senses.definition: a film, television programme, song, etc. that allows a particular performer to show their ability

examples.x: The new series has been created as a vehicle for the young star.

senses.definition: any of the tubes that carry blood from all parts of the body towards the heart

examples.x: the jugular vein
The nurse was having trouble finding a vein in his arm.

senses.definition: any of the very thin tubes that form the frame of a leaf or an insect’s wing
a narrow area of a different colour in some types of stone, wood and cheese
a thin layer of minerals or metal contained in rock

examples.x: a vein of gold

senses.definition: an amount of a particular quality or feature in something

examples.x: They had tapped a rich vein of information in his secretary.
There was a vein of proverbial wisdom in what he said.

senses.definition: a particular style or manner

examples.x: A number of other people commented in a similar vein.
‘And that's not all,’ he continued in angry vein.
Other speakers tackled the same problem in a lighter vein.
Fortunately, the rest of the evening continued in a lighter vein.

senses.definition: a business project or activity, especially one that involves taking risks

examples.x: A disastrous business venture lost him thousands of dollars.

senses.definition: to go somewhere even though you know that it might be dangerous or unpleasant

examples.x: They ventured nervously into the water.
He's never ventured abroad in his life.

senses.definition: to say or do something in a careful way, especially because it might upset or offend somebody

examples.x: She hardly dared to venture an opinion.
He ventured a tentative smile.
I ventured to suggest that she might have made a mistake.
‘And if I say no?’ she ventured.
He ventured that the data might be flawed.

senses.definition: to risk losing something valuable or important if you are not successful at something

examples.x: It was wrong to venture his financial security on such a risky deal.

senses.definition: used to say that you have to take risks if you want to achieve things and be successful
a place where people meet for an organized event, for example a concert, sporting event or conference

examples.x: The band will be playing at 20 different venues on their UK tour.
music/entertainment venues
Please note the change of venue for this event.

senses.definition: relating to words

examples.x: The job applicant must have good verbal skills.
non-verbal communication (= expressions of the face, gestures, etc.)

senses.definition: spoken, not written

examples.x: a verbal agreement/warning
verbal instructions

senses.definition: relating to verbs

examples.x: a verbal noun (= a noun formed from a verb, for example smoking)

senses.definition: an official judgement made in court or at an inquest (= an official investigation into somebody's death)

examples.x: Has the jury reached a verdict?
The jury returned a verdict (= gave a verdict) of guilty.
The coroner recorded a verdict of accidental death.

senses.definition: a decision that you make or an opinion that you give about something, after you have tested it or considered it carefully

examples.x: Well, what's your verdict?
The panel will give their verdict on the latest album releases.

senses.definition: to check that something is true or accurate

examples.x: We have no way of verifying his story.
Please verify that there is sufficient memory available before loading the program.
Please verify that your password was entered correctly.
I'll leave you to verify whether these claims are true.

senses.definition: to show or say that something is true or accurate

examples.x: Her version of events was verified by neighbours.
Several witnesses verified his story.

senses.definition: writing that is arranged in lines, often with a regular rhythm or pattern of rhyme

examples.x: Most of the play is written in verse, but some of it is in prose.

senses.definition: a group of lines that form a unit in a poem or song

examples.x: a hymn with six verses

senses.definition: poetry

examples.x: a book of comic verses

senses.definition: any one of the short numbered divisions of a chapter in the Bible

examples.x: She always read a few verses from the Bible before going to bed.

senses.definition: the exact details of something, especially the exact place where particular information may be found

examples.x: I can't give chapter and verse, but that's the rough outline of our legal position.

senses.definition: a form of something that is slightly different from an earlier form or from other forms of the same thing

examples.x: the latest version of the software package
an expanded version of the article
The original/final version is vastly superior.
a new/different/modified/revised version
an earlier/a previous version
an updated version of the app
a print/an online version
to create/produce/offer/release/use a version
There are two versions of the game, a long one and a short one.
the DVD version of the film
This amended version of the bill went to the Senate.
an edited version of her speech to the National Press Club in Canberra
the full version of the report
the de luxe/luxury version
I've only played the version for PC.
This is an edited version of the review.

senses.definition: a film, play, piece of music, etc. that is based on a particular piece of work but is in a different form, style or language

examples.x: the film version of ‘War and Peace’
The English version of the novel is due for publication next year.
He also starred in the stage version.
an animated version of the story
an instrumental version of the song
The piece also exists in a version for two pianos.
an abridged version for children
He wrote his own version of the legend.

senses.definition: a description of an event from the point of view of a particular person or group of people

examples.x: We have no way of knowing which version is true.
She gave us her version of what had happened that day.
Their versions of how the accident happened conflict.
She agreed to give her version of events to journalists.
Each side has its own version of the truth.

senses.definition: used to show that two teams or sides are against each other

examples.x: It is France versus Brazil in the final.
in the case of the State versus Ford

senses.definition: used to compare two different ideas, choices, etc.

examples.x: It was the promise of better job opportunities versus the inconvenience of moving away and leaving her friends.

senses.definition: going straight up or down from a level surface or from top to bottom in a picture, etc.

examples.x: the vertical axis of the graph
The cliff was almost vertical.
There was a vertical drop to the ocean.

senses.definition: having a structure in which there are top, middle and bottom levels

examples.x: a vertical flow of communication

senses.definition: passed from one generation to the next

examples.x: 4% of these infections result from vertical transmission from mother to baby.

senses.definition: used to emphasize that you are talking about a particular thing or person and not about another

examples.x: He might be phoning her at this very moment.
The US initiated the deal for that very reason.
I'd intended to tell him that very day.
Those were her very words.
That's the very thing I need.

senses.definition: used to emphasize an extreme place or time

examples.x: It happens at the very beginning of the book.
Education is at the very top of our list of priorities.
at the very end of the film
The proposed site is in the very heart of the city.
It was clear from the very start that he was in no mood to compromise.
The news thrilled me to the very core of my being.

senses.definition: used to emphasize a noun

examples.x: The very nature of its business is to secretly monitor and profile internet users' habits.
a civil war in which the very existence of the nation is in question
The very fact that the Army is now polling its members on the subject suggests it may be softening its stance.
‘I can't do that!’ she gasped, appalled at the very idea.
The very thought of drink made him feel sick.
Many readers will scoff at the very notion.
The novel captures the very essence of life in nineteenth-century France.

senses.definition: in somebody’s presence; in front of somebody

examples.x: He had seen his life's work destroyed before his very eyes.
Before our very eyes, the bird snatched the fish from the plate and flew off.

senses.definition: used before adjectives, adverbs and determiners to mean ‘in a high degree’ or ‘extremely’

examples.x: Very few people know that.
We have very little information at present on the incident.
Thanks very much.
I'm not very (= not at all) impressed.
I'm very very grateful.
Things could have been so very different.
Australia has a very good reputation for producing high-quality grain.
This is a very important part of our marketing.
very small
very quickly
‘Do you like it?’ ‘Yeah, I do. Very much.’
‘Is it what you expected?’ ‘Oh yes, very much so.’
My children are still very young.
‘Are you busy?’ ‘Not very.’
The new building has been very much admired.
very hard/difficult
very popular/happy/successful
These results are very worrying.
We were obviously very pleased with the outcome.
I find the film very upsetting to watch.

senses.definition: used to emphasize a superlative adjective or before own

examples.x: They wanted the very best quality.
Be there by six at the very latest.
At last he had his very own car (= belonging to him and to nobody else).
It's the very worst time to be trying to sell your house.

senses.definition: exactly the same

examples.x: Mario said the very same thing.

senses.definition: a tube that carries blood through the body of a person or an animal, or liquid through the parts of a plant

examples.x: to burst/rupture a blood vessel

senses.definition: a ship or large boat

examples.x: ocean-going vessels
a small fishing vessel

senses.definition: a container used for holding liquids, such as a bowl, cup, etc.

examples.x: a Bronze Age drinking vessel
ancient bronze ritual vessels

senses.definition: a person who has a lot of experience in a particular area or activity

examples.x: the veteran American actor, Clint Eastwood

senses.definition: a person who has been a soldier, sailor, etc. in a war

examples.x: war veterans
a veteran of the Spanish Civil War

senses.definition: through a place

examples.x: We flew home via Dubai.

senses.definition: by means of a particular person, system, etc.

examples.x: I heard about the sale via Jane.
The news programme came to us via satellite.

senses.definition: that can be done; that will be successful

examples.x: a viable option/proposition
There is no viable alternative.
to be commercially/politically/financially/economically viable
If there was any delay then the rescue plan would cease to be viable.

senses.definition: capable of developing and surviving independently

examples.x: viable organisms

senses.definition: full of life and energy

examples.x: a vibrant city
Thailand is at its most vibrant during the New Year celebrations.

senses.definition: very bright and strong

examples.x: The room was decorated in vibrant reds and yellows.

senses.definition: loud and powerful

examples.x: vibrant rhythms

senses.definition: criminal activities that involve sex or drugs

examples.x: At the door were two plain-clothes detectives from the vice squad.
The bright 21-year-old turned to a secret life of vice after getting bored with her studies at college.

senses.definition: behaviour that is evil or immoral; a quality in somebody’s character that is evil or immoral

examples.x: The film ended most satisfactorily: vice punished and virtue rewarded.
Greed is a terrible vice.
Chocolate brownies are my only vice.

senses.definition: a tool with two metal blocks that can be moved together by turning a screw. The vice is used to hold an object in place while work is done on it.

examples.x: He held my arm in a vice-like (= very firm) grip.

senses.definition: violent and cruel

examples.x: a vicious attack
a vicious criminal
She has a vicious temper.
Police described the robbery as particularly vicious.

senses.definition: aggressive and dangerous

examples.x: a vicious dog

senses.definition: full of hate and anger

examples.x: She wrote me a vicious letter.
The newspapers launched a vicious attack on him, forcing him to resign.
The article was vicious in its criticism of the prime minister.

senses.definition: very bad or severe

examples.x: a vicious headache
a vicious spiral of rising prices

senses.definition: a person who has been attacked, injured or killed as the result of a crime, a disease, an accident, etc.

examples.x: shooting/murder victims
flood/crash/accident victims
an innocent/unsuspecting victim
victims of crime/abuse/violence
the alleged victim of a serious assault
Several countries have pledged millions of dollars to help the victims of the tsunami.
The team will try to identify potential victims of domestic violence.
flood/disaster/earthquake/hurricane victims
cancer/stroke/heart attack victims
families/relatives of the victims
expressions of sympathy for the victims and their families
He made a victim impact statement to the court.

senses.definition: a person who has been tricked

examples.x: They were the victims of a cruel hoax.
The site offers help and advice for anyone who has been the victim of a scam.

senses.definition: a person or thing that is badly affected by a situation, a decision, etc.

examples.x: Schools are the latest victims of cuts in public spending.
The small company became a victim of its own success when it could not supply all its orders on time.

senses.definition: an animal or a person that is killed and offered as a sacrifice

examples.x: a sacrificial victim

senses.definition: to be injured, cheated, damaged or killed by somebody/something

examples.x: Many plants have fallen victim to the sudden frost.

senses.definition: success in a game, an election, a war, etc.

examples.x: to win a narrow victory
The outcome left both sides claiming victory.
an election victory
Neither side is strong enough to achieve a military victory.
a decisive/landslide victory in the election
She is confident of victory in Saturday's final.
The team are celebrating a 3–2 victory over Poland.
He hopes to lead his side to victory against Australia.
The case is being seen as a victory for freedom of speech.
a victory speech/celebration/parade

senses.definition: to win something easily

examples.x: He swept to victory in the final of the championship.
Labour swept to victory in the 1945 election.

senses.definition: to win something even though it seemed up until the last moment that you would lose
a system of recording moving pictures and sound, either using a digital method of storing data or (in the past) using videotape

examples.x: A wedding is the perfect subject for video.
The robbery was captured on video.
Most of the movie was shot on digital video.

senses.definition: a short film or recording of an event, made using digital technology and viewed on a computer, especially over the internet

examples.x: The school made a short promotional video.
More than a million people have watched a video of the incident.
She posted a series of videos on the internet.
Upload your videos and share them with friends and family online.
This phone can store up to 20 hours of video.

senses.definition: a short film made by a pop or rock band to be shown with a song when it is played on television or online

examples.x: The group's new video will be released next month.
The band are in Iceland doing a video shoot.

senses.definition: a type of magnetic tape used in the past for recording moving pictures and sound; a box containing this tape, also called a video cassette

examples.x: The movie was released on video later that year.

senses.definition: a copy of a film, programme, etc. recorded on videotape

examples.x: We used to rent videos nearly every weekend.

senses.definition: a piece of equipment used, especially in the past, to record and play films and TV programmes on video

examples.x: I never even learned to programme the video.

senses.definition: what you can see from a particular place or position, especially beautiful countryside

examples.x: There were magnificent views of the surrounding countryside.
Most rooms enjoy panoramic views of the ocean.
The view from the top of the tower was spectacular.
a sea/mountain view
I'd like a room with a view.

senses.definition: used when you are talking about whether you can see something or whether something can be seen in a particular situation

examples.x: The lake soon came into view.
The sun disappeared from view.
Tensions within the band remained hidden from public view.
There was nobody in view.
I hid in the hallway out of view.
Sit down—you're blocking my view.
I didn't have a good view of the stage.

senses.definition: a personal opinion about something; an attitude towards something

examples.x: to have strong political views
She and I hold opposing views on the matter.
His views on the subject were well known.
The meeting will give people the opportunity to express their views about the issue.
We take the view that it would be wrong to interfere.
This evidence supports the view that there is too much violence on television.
I, on the other hand, take a different view.
I am afraid I do not share this view.
My own/personal view is that…
In my view it was a waste of time.
There was a frank exchange of views (= an angry argument) between Dr Wilson and the other members of the committee.

senses.definition: a way of understanding or thinking about something

examples.x: He has an optimistic view of life.
the Christian view of the world
The book gives readers an inside view of political life.
The traditional view was that marriage was meant to last.

senses.definition: an occasion when a video is watched online

examples.x: His performance went viral, attracting over 8 million views on YouTube.

senses.definition: a photograph or picture that shows an interesting place or scene

examples.x: a book with views of Paris
On his visits he painted views of the town and the surrounding countryside.

senses.definition: a special chance to see or admire something
a view of something from a high position looking down

examples.x: From the plane we had a bird's-eye view of Manhattan.

senses.definition: to have a particular aim, plan, etc. in your mind

examples.x: He wanted to make money and went abroad with this end in view.

senses.definition: to appear, especially when moving gradually closer from a long way off

examples.x: A ship hove into sight.
Like a galleon in full sail, Cara hove into view.

senses.definition: that can be seen completely, directly in front of somebody/something

examples.x: He was shot in full view of a large crowd.

senses.definition: considering something

examples.x: In view of the weather, the event will now be held indoors.

senses.definition: being shown in a public place so that people can look at it

examples.x: The new discoveries will be on view in London in the spring.
The carriage was put on view for the public to see.

senses.definition: to think somebody/something is bad; to not have a good opinion of somebody/something

examples.x: She took a dim view of my suggestion.

senses.definition: to consider what is likely to happen or be important over a long period of time rather than only considering the present situation

examples.x: As pension funds are investing for members’ retirements, they can take the long view.

senses.definition: with the intention or hope of doing something

examples.x: He's painting the house with a view to selling it.

senses.definition: to think about somebody/something in a particular way

examples.x: How do you view your position within the company?
The plan was not viewed favourably by the public.
to view something as a threat/an opportunity
He is widely viewed as a possible leader.
When the car was first built, the design was viewed as highly original.
She viewed him with suspicion.
You should view their offer with a great deal of caution.

senses.definition: to look at something, especially when you look carefully

examples.x: People came from all over the world to view her work.
The eclipse should only be viewed through a special lens.
These paintings were meant to be viewed from a distance.
A viewing platform gave stunning views over the valley.

senses.definition: to visit a house, etc. before deciding whether to buy or rent it

examples.x: The property can only be viewed by appointment.

senses.definition: to watch television, a film, etc.

examples.x: The show has a viewing audience of six million (= six million people watch it).
Saturday's screening will be an opportunity to view the movie before it goes on general release.

senses.definition: a person watching television or a video on the internet

examples.x: The programme attracted millions of viewers.
British television viewers saw him this week in a BBC documentary.
The average American TV viewer spends five hours a day watching the small screen.
an attempt to attract younger viewers
Her performance has grabbed the attention of 100 million YouTube viewers.
a regular viewer of the show

senses.definition: a person who looks at or considers something

examples.x: Some of her art is intended to shock the viewer.
Many informed viewers of the current political scene are becoming critical of the government.

senses.definition: a device for looking at slides (= photographs on special film), for example a small box with a light in it
a way of thinking about a subject

examples.x: Try looking at things from a different viewpoint.
From a practical viewpoint, I'd advise you not to go.
She will have her own viewpoint on the matter.

senses.definition: a direction or place from which you look at something

examples.x: The artist has painted the scene from various viewpoints.

senses.definition: a very small town located in a country area

examples.x: We visited towns and villages all over Spain.
a meeting in the village hall
a remote/nearby/neighbouring village
Residents of the village are unhappy with the bus service.
a fishing village
a small/tiny village
rural villages
a mountain/seaside village
I soon got to know everybody in the village.
the village of Boscastle in Cornwall
the village shop
Her books are about village life.

senses.definition: the people who live in a village

examples.x: The whole village was invited to the party.

senses.definition: a person who lives in a village

examples.x: Some of the villagers have lived here all their lives.

senses.definition: to go against or refuse to obey a law, an agreement, etc.

examples.x: to violate international law

senses.definition: to upset or not respect somebody’s peace, privacy, etc.

examples.x: She accused the press photographers of violating her privacy.

senses.definition: to damage or destroy a holy or special place

examples.x: to violate a grave

senses.definition: to force somebody to have sex

examples.x: He had drugged her and then violated her.

senses.definition: the act of going against or refusing to obey a law, an agreement, etc.

examples.x: They were in open violation of the treaty.

senses.definition: the act of not respecting somebody's rights, peace, privacy, etc.

examples.x: gross violations of human rights

senses.definition: the act of damaging or destroying a holy or special place

examples.x: This was a violation of a sacred space.

senses.definition: the act of forcing somebody to have sex
violent behaviour that is intended to hurt or kill somebody

examples.x: Police do not think this killing was a random act of violence.
He condemned the protesters' use of violence against the police.
domestic violence (= between family members)
These people live under a constant threat of violence.
Our organization works with victims of violence.
Why do they always have to resort to violence?
Violence broke out inside the prison last night.
Violence erupted between police and demonstrators.
Is there too much sex and violence on TV?

senses.definition: physical or emotional force and energy

examples.x: The violence of her feelings surprised him.
the violence of the eruption
He reacted to the idea with some violence.

senses.definition: to damage something or have a bad effect on it

examples.x: This version of the play does violence to Shakespeare's text.

senses.definition: involving or caused by physical force that is intended to hurt or kill somebody

examples.x: violent crime/criminals
violent protests/attacks/incidents
Students were involved in violent clashes with the police.
The crowd suddenly turned violent.
Was he ever violent towards you?
violent acts/behaviour
He met with a violent death (= he was murdered, killed in a fight, etc.).
They don't allow their kids to play violent video games (= that show a lot of violence).
Their father was a violent man.

senses.definition: showing or caused by very strong emotion

examples.x: Toddlers can be prone to violent outbursts.
There was a violent reaction from the public.
The whole thing became the subject of violent controversy.

senses.definition: very strong and sudden

examples.x: I took a violent dislike to him.
a violent storm
a violent explosion
a violent headache
a violent change

senses.definition: extremely bright

examples.x: Her dress was a violent pink.

senses.definition: made to appear to exist by the use of computer software, for example on the internet

examples.x: a system to help programmers create virtual environments
a virtual classroom/desktop/library
You can also take a virtual tour of the museum.
Students will have more access to resources and support, both virtual and physical.

senses.definition: almost or very nearly the thing described, so that any slight difference is not important

examples.x: The company has a virtual monopoly in this area of trade.
The economy has come to a virtual standstill.
He married a virtual stranger.
The country was sliding into a state of virtual civil war.
Analysts said the deal was a virtual certainty.
The stunning battle sequences almost make up for the virtual absence of a plot.
She was a virtual unknown when he cast her in the film.

senses.definition: behaviour or attitudes that show high moral standards

examples.x: He led a life of virtue.
She was certainly no paragon of virtue (= her moral standards were very far from perfect).

senses.definition: a particular good quality or habit

examples.x: Patience is not one of her virtues, I'm afraid.
As a politician, he always emphasized the virtues of compromise and conciliation.

senses.definition: an attractive or useful quality

examples.x: The plan has the virtue of simplicity.
He was extolling the virtues of the internet.
They could see no virtue in discussing it further.

senses.definition: by means of or because of something

examples.x: She got the job by virtue of her greater experience.

senses.definition: to manage to present as a good quality something that other people might consider to be bad

examples.x: There are artists who make a virtue of repetition.

senses.definition: to manage to gain an advantage from something that you have to do and cannot avoid

examples.x: She decided to make a virtue of necessity and combined a business trip to Paris with a visit to her cousins there.

senses.definition: willing to have sex with anyone

examples.x: a woman of easy virtue

senses.definition: the reward for acting in a moral or correct way is the knowledge that you have done so, and you should not expect more than this, for example praise from other people or payment
a living thing, too small to be seen without a microscope, that causes disease in people, animals and plants

examples.x: the flu/influenza virus
patients known to have been infected with the virus
the human immunodeficiency virus or HIV
the hepatitis C virus
a highly infectious disease caused by a virus
a virus infection
The vaccination offers good protection against the virus.
It is not clear how she contracted the virus.

senses.definition: a disease caused by a virus

examples.x: There's a virus going around the office.
I must have caught a virus on holiday.

senses.definition: instructions that are hidden within a computer program and are designed to cause faults or destroy data

examples.x: a computer virus
I think I've got a virus on my laptop.
The virus in the software was programmed to corrupt the hard disk.
software errors that can be exploited by virus writers

senses.definition: a stamp or mark put in your passport by officials of a foreign country that gives you permission to enter, pass through or leave their country

examples.x: to apply for a visa
an entry/tourist/transit/exit visa

senses.definition: that can be seen

examples.x: The house is clearly visible from the beach.
Most stars are not visible to the naked eye.
The moon was just visible between the clouds.

senses.definition: that is obvious enough to be noticed

examples.x: We have not noticed any visible benefits from the new system.
A more visible police presence in communities is essential to combat crime.
He showed no visible sign of emotion.
She made a visible effort to control her anger.
After using the cream for a month, I could see no visible difference.

senses.definition: the ability to see; the area that you can see from a particular position

examples.x: to have good/perfect/poor/blurred/normal vision
Cats have good night vision.
Her vision was still blurry.
The disease causes a gradual loss of peripheral vision.
He glimpsed something on the edge of his vision.

senses.definition: an idea or a picture in your imagination

examples.x: Our job is to guide a client and develop a strategic vision.
He had a vision of a world in which there would be no wars.
The word conjures up visions of home and family.
The film's vision of the future is bleak.
He harboured visions of becoming party leader some day.
I had visions of us getting hopelessly lost.
These two men share a similar vision for the country.
He had a very specific vision for the future.

senses.definition: a dream or similar experience, especially of a religious kind

examples.x: The idea came to her in a vision.
He had visions regularly.
She claimed she saw a vision of the Virgin Mary.

senses.definition: the ability to think about or plan the future with great imagination and intelligence

examples.x: She had vision and determination.
a leader of vision
He's a competent politician, but he lacks vision.

senses.definition: a person of great beauty or who shows the quality mentioned

examples.x: She was a vision in white lace.
a vision of loveliness

senses.definition: the picture on a television or cinema screen

examples.x: We apologize for the loss of vision.

senses.definition: an occasion or a period of time when somebody goes to see a place or person and spends time there

examples.x: a two-day/three-day visit
the prime minister's surprise visit to the troops
an official/state visit
It's my first visit to New York.
If you have time, pay a visit to the local museum.
The family made a visit to England in the summer of 1923.
a visit to the doctor
His visits home were limited to Christmas.
We had a visit from the police last night.
Arranegments are being made for a visit by a member of the royal family.
a brief/recent visit
The team reported on deficiencies found during the site visit.
Regular visits to the dentist are important.
Is this a social visit, or is it business?
They're on an exchange visit to France.
Following this initial visit, she will return to Montserrat in June.

senses.definition: an occasion when somebody looks at a website on the internet

examples.x: Visits to our website have doubled in a year.
The site now gets about 600,000 visits a day.

senses.definition: an occasion when two or more people meet to talk in an informal way

examples.x: He thought back to his visit with the doctor.

senses.definition: to go to see a person or a place for a period of time

examples.x: My parents are coming to visit me next week.
to visit friends/family
It looks like a lovely place to visit.
to visit a country/city/town
to visit a museum/shrine
to visit a hospital/an office
to visit a home/house
She went to visit relatives in Wales.
The Prime Minister is visiting Japan at the moment.
You should visit your dentist at least twice a year.
This is an area rarely visited by Europeans.
I first visited New York in 1991.
He is planning to visit China later this month.
The best time to visit is during the winter dry season.

senses.definition: to go to a website on the internet

examples.x: For more information, visit our website.
to visit a site/page

senses.definition: to stay somewhere for a short time

examples.x: We don't live here. We're just visiting.
Ships visit the island occasionally.
The lake is also visited by seals in the summer.

senses.definition: to make an official visit to somebody, for example to perform checks or give advice

examples.x: Government inspectors are visiting schools in the area.
Council officers will be visiting premises to inspect safety arrangements.

senses.definition: a person who visits a person or place

examples.x: We've got visitors coming this weekend.
Do you get many visitors?
The theme park attracts 2.5 million visitors a year.
She's a frequent visitor to the US.
We have been regular visitors to the island for 20 years.
The festival draws visitors from all over the world.
a visitor centre/attraction

senses.definition: a person who looks at a website on the internet

examples.x: How can we attract more visitors to our website?

senses.definition: of or connected with seeing or sight

examples.x: the visual arts
The building makes a tremendous visual impact.
dramatic visual effects
visual artists
I have a very good visual memory.
A reader creates visual images of the characters in a novel.
The photographs she takes are a visual record of her travels.
The company relied on simple visual inspections of the tunnels to confirm their safety.
A driverless vehicle identifies visual cues on the road, such as other cars or traffic signs.

senses.definition: necessary or essential in order for something to succeed or exist

examples.x: the vitamins that are vital for health
Patience and a cool head are vital for investors.
Good financial accounts are vital to the success of any enterprise.
Reading is of vital importance in language learning.
The police play a vital role in our society.
Small chemist shops are a vital part of many local communities.
'We are prepared to use force to protect our vital interests in the region,' he said
The website provides vital information for tourists.
It is vital that you keep accurate records when you are self-employed.

examples.cf: it is vital to do something
examples.x: It was vital to show that he was not afraid.

examples.cf: it is vital for somebody/something to do something
examples.x: It is absolutely vital for cities to have public green spaces.

senses.definition: connected with or necessary for staying alive

examples.x: the vital organs (= the brain, heart, lungs, etc.)

senses.definition: full of energy and enthusiasm
a natural substance found in food that is an essential part of what humans and animals need to help them grow and stay healthy. There are many different vitamins.

examples.x: vitamin A/B/D/E
The plants are an excellent source of vitamins and minerals.
vitamin supplements
breakfast cereals enriched with vitamins
She tried changing her diet and taking vitamins.
vitamin deficiency
vitamin pills
Many juices are fortified with vitamins.

senses.definition: connected with the voice

examples.x: vocal music
the vocal organs (= the tongue, lips, etc.)

senses.definition: telling people your opinions or protesting about something loudly and with confidence

examples.x: He has been very vocal in his criticism of the government's policy.
The protesters are a small but vocal minority.

senses.definition: the sound or sounds produced through the mouth by a person speaking or singing

examples.x: I could hear voices in the next room.
He recognized Sarah's voice.
to speak in a deep/soft/loud voice
‘I promise,’ she said in a small voice (= a quiet, shy voice).
There was a note of concern in his voice.
He never raised his voice (= spoke loudly in an angry way) to the children.
to lower your voice (= to speak more quietly)
Keep your voice down (= speak quietly).
Don't take that tone of voice with me!
The men turned around at the sound of my voice.
Her voice shook with emotion.
‘There you are,’ said a voice behind me.
When did his voice break (= become deep like a man's)?
Her voice sounded familiar.
He was suffering from flu and had lost his voice (= could not speak).
She has a good singing voice.
She was in good voice (= singing well) at the concert tonight.

senses.definition: having a voice of the type mentioned

examples.x: low-voiced
squeaky-voiced

senses.definition: the right to express your opinion and influence decisions

examples.x: Employees should have a voice in the decision-making process.
Refugees have been unable to find a voice in politics.

senses.definition: a particular attitude, opinion or feeling that is expressed; a feeling or an opinion that you become aware of inside yourself

examples.x: He pledged that his party would listen to the voice of the people.
Very few dissenting voices were heard on the right of the party.
the voice of reason/sanity/conscience
‘Coward!’ a tiny inner voice insisted.

senses.definition: an organization that expresses the opinion of a particular section of society

examples.x: The Royal Society is the voice of the British science establishment.

senses.definition: the form of a verb that shows whether the subject of a sentence performs the action (the active voice) or is affected by it (the passive voice)

examples.x: Can you turn this sentence into the passive voice?

senses.definition: sound produced by movement of the vocal cords used in the pronunciation of vowels and some consonants
as loudly as possible

examples.x: She was screaming at the top of her voice.
I was shouting at the top of my voice but she couldn't hear me.

senses.definition: to be able to speak or express your opinion
to express your feelings, worries, etc.

examples.x: Many workers at the meeting gave voice to their fears about job security.

senses.definition: to like talking a lot or too much, usually without wanting to listen to other people

examples.x: She’s much too fond of the sound of her own voice.

senses.definition: to express your feelings, opinions, etc. in a way that makes people notice and consider them

examples.x: The programme gives ordinary viewers a chance to make their voices heard.
a society in which individuals are able to make their voices heard

senses.definition: the voice of God or your conscience, that tells you to do what is morally right
as a group; with everyone agreeing

examples.x: The various opposition parties speak with one voice on this issue.
The teachers speak with one voice when they demand an end to the cuts.

senses.definition: the amount of space that an object or a substance fills; the amount of space that a container has

examples.x: How do you measure the volume of a gas?
In the experiment, lighted candles were put under jars of different volumes.
Patients showed an improvement in lung volume.
Wait until the dough doubles in volume before kneading it again.

senses.definition: the amount of something

examples.x: the sheer volume (= large amount) of business
New roads are being built to cope with the increased volume of traffic.
Sales volumes fell 0.2% in June.
The total volume of exports fell by 14.5 per cent.
an attempt to increase the volume of trade
powerful computers that can handle large volumes of data
This work has grown in volume recently.
Due to the volume of mail Mary receives, she may not be able to respond to individual inquiries.

senses.definition: the amount of sound that is produced by a television, radio, etc.

examples.x: to turn the volume up/down
This music is best played at very high volume.
The song has been recorded at a low volume.
He adjusted the volume on his phone.

senses.definition: a book that is part of a series of books

examples.x: an encyclopedia in 20 volumes
The encyclopedia is a huge work, running to 20 volumes.
a companion volume to the one on African wildlife

senses.definition: a book

examples.x: a library of over 50 000 volumes
She published her first book, a slim volume of poetry, at the age of sixteen.

senses.definition: a series of different issues of the same magazine, especially all the issues for one year

examples.x: ‘New Scientist’ volume 142, number 3

senses.definition: to tell you a lot about something/somebody, without the need for words

examples.x: His achievement speaks volumes for his determination.
What you wear speaks volumes about you.

senses.definition: done willingly, not because you are forced

examples.x: a voluntary agreement
Attendance on the course is purely voluntary.
to pay voluntary contributions into a pension fund
He took voluntary redundancy.

senses.definition: done by people who choose to do it without being paid

examples.x: I do some voluntary work at the local hospital.
She works there on a voluntary basis.
voluntary services/bodies/agencies/organizations (= organized, controlled or supported by people who choose to do this and are usually not paid)
the voluntary sector (= organizations which are set up to help people and that do not make a profit, for example charities)

senses.definition: doing a job without wanting to be paid for it

examples.x: The homeless hostel is staffed by voluntary workers.

senses.definition: that you can control
a person who does a job without being paid for it

examples.x: Schools need volunteers to help children to read.
She does volunteer work at an orphanage.
She was a volunteer for the Red Cross before training as a nurse.
Volunteers from various organizations are working to save the lives of the earthquake victims.
a volunteer firefighter
volunteer helpers/carers
The Centre is run by a group of dedicated volunteers.

senses.definition: a person who offers to do something without being forced to do it

examples.x: Are there any volunteers to help clear up?
For my next trick, I'll need a volunteer from the audience.
The company is looking for volunteers to take part in a trial.
Hundreds of volunteers have come forward to offer their help.

senses.definition: a person who chooses to join the armed forces without being forced to join
to offer to do something without being forced to do it or without getting paid for it

examples.x: He has been volunteering for 11 years now.
Jill volunteered to organize a petition.
I volunteered to help clean up the beach.
Several staff members volunteered for early retirement.
He volunteered as a translator for Spanish-speaking patients.
Workers volunteer their time, as no funds are available to pay professional staff.
He volunteered his services as a driver.
She has been volunteering her computer skills for the foundation.

senses.definition: to suggest something or tell somebody something without being asked

examples.x: to volunteer advice
Nobody asked her, and she didn't volunteer any information.
‘I could lend you some books,’ he volunteered.

senses.definition: to join the army, etc. without being forced to

examples.x: He wasn't conscripted. He volunteered.
to volunteer for military service
I volunteered for service in the Air Force.
More than a hundred thousand Irish men and women volunteered to serve in the British armed forces during World War II.

senses.definition: to suggest somebody for a job or an activity, even though they may not want to do it

examples.x: They volunteered me for the job of interpreter.
Her dad had volunteered her to help put away the equipment.

senses.definition: a formal choice that you make in an election or at a meeting in order to choose somebody or decide something

examples.x: to win/lose votes
You can cast your vote at the local polling station.
He took 53% of the votes in the election.
They've started opening the ballot boxes and counting the votes.
No candidate gained a majority of the votes in the first round.
The Tory candidate received only 4203 votes.
There were 21 votes for and 17 against the motion, with 2 abstentions.
The motion was passed by 6 votes to 3.
The Green candidate won over 3 000 of the 14 000 votes cast.

senses.definition: an occasion when a group of people vote on something

examples.x: to win/lose a vote
to have/take/hold a vote on an issue
We saw today a decisive vote in favour of (= for) industrial action.
The issue was put to the vote.
The vote was unanimous.
He called on the government to delay the vote to authorize military action.
Decisions have to be ratified by a majority vote.

senses.definition: the right to vote, especially in political elections

examples.x: In Britain and the US, people get the vote at 18.
How many years is it since women have had the vote?
legislation to give prisoners the vote

senses.definition: the total number of votes in an election

examples.x: She obtained 40% of the vote.
The party increased their share of the vote.

senses.definition: the vote given by a particular group of people, or for a particular party, etc.

examples.x: the student vote
the Labour vote
the Hispanic/Latino vote

senses.definition: to show formally by marking a paper, raising your hand, using a voting machine, etc. which person you want to win an election, or which plan or idea you support

examples.x: How did you vote at the last election?
Only about half of the electorate bothered to vote.
to vote for a candidate/party/bill
Did you vote for or against her?
Over 60% of members voted in favour of (= for) the motion.
We'll listen to the arguments on both sides and then vote on it.
About 1.8 million people voted in the election.
We voted Democrat in the last election.
to vote yes/no
The board voted unanimously not to file for bankruptcy.
The Senate voted overwhelmingly to retain sanctions.
Parliament voted to set up an independent inquiry into the matter.
The meeting voted that the town council should reject the scheme.
Everyone over 18 has the right to vote.
to be registered/eligible to vote

senses.definition: to choose somebody/something for a position or an award by voting

examples.x: He was voted most promising new director.
The College of Cardinals voted him Pope.
The New York Film Critics Circle voted it their Best Picture of the Year.

senses.definition: to say that something is good or bad

examples.x: The event was voted a great success.

senses.definition: to agree to give somebody/yourself something by voting

examples.x: The directors have just voted themselves a huge pay increase.

senses.definition: to suggest something or support a suggestion that somebody has made

examples.x: I vote (that) we go out to eat.

senses.definition: to show what you think about something by going or not going somewhere

examples.x: Shoppers voted with their feet and avoided the store.

senses.definition: the action of choosing somebody/something in an election or at a meeting

examples.x: He was eliminated in the first round of voting.
Voting will take place on May 1.
tactical voting
to be of voting age
She was elected on the second round of voting.

senses.definition: to make a formal and serious promise to do something or a formal statement that is true

examples.x: She vowed never to speak to him again.
He vowed (that) he had not hurt her.
They vowed eternal friendship.
‘I'll be back,’ she vowed.

senses.definition: the fact of being weak and easily hurt physically or emotionally

examples.x: the vulnerability of newborn babies to disease
financial vulnerability
He was intensely aware of his own vulnerability.

senses.definition: weak and easily hurt physically or emotionally

examples.x: These offices are highly vulnerable to terrorist attack.
Old people are particularly vulnerable to the flu.
She looked very vulnerable standing there on her own.
In cases of food poisoning, young children are especially vulnerable.
The sudden resignation of the financial director put the company in a very vulnerable position.
We should protect the most vulnerable members of our society.
Animals are at their most vulnerable when searching for food for their young.
